text_blocks.text: Within that time, I would like -- or that my answer is clear on the question of the significance of this proviso which reads, "Provided further that the provisions of this section shall also apply to the cases of aliens who come to the main land from the insular possessions."
The question was, we're the Filipinos aliens?
That was the question.
Do I understand correctly?
And may answer --

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes.
Are they included in that -- are they included in that word alien?
That is right.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes.
That is the question.
My answer to that was posed upon the entirety, the composite of all the statutes as they applied in 1951 when this conviction took place as I must treat the statute.
But if I were to look back to 1931, not to determine what the statute says but what light we can get on what they might have been thinking at that time, what they considered aliens then.
Of course, the Filipinos at that time were not aliens but that leads me to the concluding matter which I cannot stress sufficiently.
That between that time and the time that the offense was committed, many statutes have changed.

That's why we were passed up the present state of the statutes, and most particularly, the statutes on page 7 of the Government's brief, the Filipino Independence Act which up to the 1946, made such clear provisions that the Immigration Act of 1917, which we've been talking about, relating to the immigration, exclusion, or expulsion -- may I finish the sentence?

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes, of course.
-- of aliens, the citizens -- the citizens of the Philippine Islands are to be considered as if they were aliens.

And then in 1946 -- that is further down on page 7, there was a complete sweep divorcing them entirely from nationality and giving them certain benefits to which Mr. Justice Frankfurter directed attention which I had here available.

So that, between that time and now, there were these statutes which completely made aliens out of the Filipinos so that as of 1951, when this conviction took place, there's no question about their being aliens, no question about the intent of the Congress as evidenced by all these statutes taken together to include them within the scope and to deport.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Now, may I ask you -- maybe you can answer at one word, yes or no.
Do the -- are these Filipinos included in that word aliens?
You --
Where?

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: You have -- you have told us what a lot of other things mean but you didn't tell or state --
As -- as of today, definitely yes.
No question about it.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: So, they are included in this proviso?
Today.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: As it read then, as you quoted here in the -- as you quoted here, as you quoted in your brief.
Mr. Chief Justice, we'll recall at the outset as pointed out that there was the 1937 -- one status and there is the present status which controls as of today.
I will answer the question on either one which is -- which date are you referring to?

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: [Laughs] Well, I'll let it go at that.
[Laughter]
Thank you.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well -- well, may I just say before you sit down.
Yes, sir.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I assume you do not want to leave the impression that whether or not a Filipino resident in the United States, who when he came here was a Filipino national, is included in the terms of the Act of February 18, 1931, any alien which is the real question before us.
I take it, you do not mean to leave the impression that that question is determined by our construction of the proviso about what we've been talking about, do you?
Absolutely not.
It is controlled --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes.
-- by the Filipino Independence Act which we have set forth here.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, I thought it might have some bearing because you -- you read -- read the proviso that just preceded it as -- as being very important to your case and I thought that possibly that --
Well, I --

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- the next proviso might also have a bearing on it.
I read all of these provisos as I stated at the outset to demonstrate two things to the Court.
One, that there were elements of manner and only those elements of manner were carried out.

Who should do the deporting in 19, where they should go to in 20?Things like that but that these provisos that were not pertinent, that were only pertinent dependent upon the rest of this whole complex of statues that in those cases, the pertinence as -- as to carry over was wasn't ill.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I -- I think that --
They were not matters of manner, they were questions of who shall be deported, not how they shall be deported, and as such, had no place in the 1931 Act.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I -- I -- having led you to make one answer of what of -- to clear what I didn't mean.
Yes, sir.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I suppose you agree -- suppose one agrees that in construing any part of the immigration laws, the whole network of legislation becomes relevant for consideration.
This was it.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: All I -- all I meant to ask you is whether you want to leave the impression that -- that that proviso is controlling not that it's relevant.
You would say it's relevant but it's not controlling.
Correct.
Thank you.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: May I -- may ask you one question --
Surely.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- which I'm a little confused on.
[Laughs]

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: This 19 that you have copied here on brief --
In the brief or the separate one?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- on page 3, 4 and 5 of your brief.
Is that from the Act of 1917 precisely as it appeared in that Act?
In 1917, subject only to the amendments of the Reorganization Act which substituted the Attorney General for the Secretary of Labor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But for that --
It reads as of 1917.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: As the way it came on down there.
At that time.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Now --
And that slipped.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: In 19 -- in 1917, I don't know it hasn't relevance at all but I'm -- it inquires that they procure.
In 1917, when this was written, would you say that a Filipino was an alien or not an alien?
Or he was not alien in 1970.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: He was not.

That preceded the a whole string of acts which are set forth in our brief later but notably, I must hammer again, the Filipino Independence Act which specifically said, "They were to be treated as aliens and then on page 7 of our brief, really buttoned it up in 1946, when they were completely divorced from the United States.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But at the time of this Act was written, they were not treated as aliens, I understood you to say.
Correctly, correctly.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Thank you.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But they were not --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: They were not.
Not only there weren't treated as such, they were not.
You can say that categorically, can't you?
Very.
Yes, I hope I made that clear.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Bishop.
I understand that I have one minute.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Alright, go right at it.
I would like to take the opportunity to correct an error that occurs in our brief on page 19 and which House Report 1513 should read House Report 1365.
I would like to make one further comment.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Wait a minute.
May I trouble you, state that again.
On page 19, house report at the bottom of the page, the end of the quotation, 1513 in incorrect.
It should read 1365.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Thank you.
I'd like to make one other comment.

The case of Bugajewitz against Adams which was relied on so heavily by the Government, the Congress had amended specifically a three-year statute of limitations in a 1907 Act by passing in 1910, an act which cut out the statute of limitations.

It was that that Mr. Justice Holmes was talking about in that opinion, that vulnerable case and the reliance which the Government places upon the use of the words in the manner of have nothing whatever to do with the substance of the holding in that case.
Thank you.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: You're welcome.
